tit.e: Oranda Shogatsu (Dutch New Year Celebration in Japan)
Oranda Shogatsu (Dutch New Year Celebration in Japan)
Oranda Shogatsu (Dutch New Year Celebration in Japan)

sen.j: オランダ正月（-しょうがつ）は、江戸時代に長崎の出島在住のオランダ人たちや、江戸の蘭学者たちによって行われた、太陽暦（グレゴリオ暦）による正月元日を祝う宴である。
sen.e: Oranda Shogatsu was a celebration of the new year on the first day of the new Solar year (the Gregorian calendar) by the Dutch who were living on Dejima, Nagasaki and by Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) in Edo (Tokyo) in the Edo period.

Oranda Shogatsu was a celebration of the new year on the first day of the new Solar year (the Gregorian calendar) by the Dutch who were living on Dejima, Nagasaki and by Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) in Edo (Tokyo) in the Edo period.

Oranda Shogatsu was a celebration of the new year on the first day of the new Solar year (the Gregorian calendar) by the Dutch who were living on Dejima, Nagasaki and by Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) in Edo (Tokyo) in the Edo period.

sen.j: 「紅毛正月」などと呼ばれることもある。
sen.e: It was also called "New Year for red-heads".
It was also called 'New Year for red-heads'.
sen.cmt: 原文は「」なので' 'に修正しました。
sen.e: It was also called 'New Year for red-heads'.

sen.j: 元々は長崎出島のオランダ商館で、日本在留のオランダ人が祝っていた風習であった。
sen.e: Originally, it was a tradition carried by the Dutch who were living in Japan at the Dutch trading house in Dejima, Nagasaki.
Originally, it was a tradition carried by the Dutch who were living in Japan at the Dutch trading house in Dejima, Nagasaki.
Originally, it was a tradition carried by the Dutch who were living in Japan at the Dutch trading house in Dejima, Nagasaki.

sen.j: 江戸幕府によるキリスト教禁令のため、表だってクリスマスを祝うことができなかったオランダ人が、代わりとして冬至に合わせて「オランダ冬至」として開催し、また日本の正月の祝いをまねて太陽暦による正月元日に、出島勤めの幕府役人や出島乙名、オランダ語通詞たち日本人を招いて西洋料理を振る舞い、オランダ式の祝宴を催したのが始まりである。
sen.e: It began when, because of the ban on Christianity by the Edo Shogunate, the Dutch were not allowed to celebrate Christmas and instead, they celebrated it as "Dutch winter solstice" on the day of winter solstice; and they invited Japanese people such as officers of the feudal government in Dejima, leaders of the island and interpreters of the language and treated them with western style food on the new Solar year's day in the similar manner as the Japanese New Year celebration.

The Dutch who were not allowed to celebrate Christmas, due to the ban on Christianity by the Edo Shogunate, had started the celebration as 'Dutch winter solstice' on the day of winter solstice and they invited Japanese people such as officers of the feudal government in Dejima, leaders of the island and interpreters of the language and treated them with western style food on the new Solar year's day in the similar manner as the Japanese New Year celebration.
sen.cmt: "Dutch winter solstice"原文は「」なので' 'に修正しました。原文の語順に忠実すぎて「自然な英語の訳出」からかけ離れていたので、全文見直しました。
sen.e: The Dutch who were not allowed to celebrate Christmas, due to the ban on Christianity by the Edo Shogunate, had started the celebration as 'Dutch winter solstice' on the day of winter solstice and they invited Japanese people such as officers of the feudal government in Dejima, leaders of the island and interpreters of the language and treated them with western style food on the new Solar year's day in the similar manner as the Japanese New Year celebration.

sen.j: これを長崎の人々は阿蘭陀正月と呼んだ。
sen.e: People in Nagasaki called this 阿蘭陀正月(Dutch New Year Celebration).
People in Nagasaki called this "Oranda Shogatsu" (Dutch New Year Celebration).
sen.cmt: 阿蘭陀正月→表記の問題ではないので、漢字を残す必要はないと思い、音（読み）をローマ字化しました。" "を追加しました。
sen.e: People in Nagasaki called this "Oranda Shogatsu" (Dutch New Year Celebration).

sen.j: やがて長崎に住む日本人とりわけオランダ通詞らの家でも、これを真似てオランダ式の宴が催されることもあった。
sen.e: Then this extended to similar style parties at houses of Japanese people such as interpreters in Nagasaki.
Then this extended to similar style parties at houses of Japanese people such as interpreters in Nagasaki.
Then this extended to similar style parties at houses of Japanese people such as interpreters in Nagasaki.

sen.j: 文政年間（1818年 - 1829年）の『長崎名勝図絵』では献立が記されており、牛肉・豚肉・アヒルなどの肉料理やハム、魚のバター煮、カステラ、コーヒーなどが饗されていたようだが、招かれた日本の役人はほとんど手をつけずに持ち帰ったともいう。
sen.e: In the "Nagasaki Meisho Zue" (Encyclopedia of Nagasaki scenic beauty) book of 1818 - 1829, there were some menus recorded which included meat dishes such as beef, pork and duck, ham, fish cooked in butter, Dutch sponge cake and coffee; but most guests of Japanese officials took them back home without eating them on the spot.

In the "Nagasaki Meisho Zue" (Encyclopedia of Nagasaki scenic beauty) book of 1818 - 1829, there were some menus recorded which included meat dishes such as beef, pork and duck, ham, fish cooked in butter, Dutch sponge cake and coffee; but most guests of Japanese officials took them back home without eating them on the spot.

In the "Nagasaki Meisho Zue" (Encyclopedia of Nagasaki scenic beauty) book of 1818 - 1829, there were some menus recorded which included meat dishes such as beef, pork and duck, ham, fish cooked in butter, Dutch sponge cake and coffee; but most guests of Japanese officials took them back home without eating them on the spot.

tit.j: 江戸芝蘭堂のオランダ正月
tit.e: Oranda Shogatsu at Shiran-do in Edo (School of Dutch Study in Tokyo)
Oranda Shogatsu at Shiran-do in Edo (School of Dutch Study in Tokyo)
Oranda Shogatsu at Shiran-do in Edo (School of Dutch Study in Tokyo)

sen.j: 江戸時代中期に活躍した通詞吉雄耕牛（幸左衛門）の自宅は、2階にオランダから輸入された家具を配して「阿蘭陀坐敷」と呼ばれており、庭園もオランダ渡りの動植物にあふれ、長崎の名所となっていた。
sen.e: The house of Kogu YOSHIO (Kozaemon), who was an interpreter in the mid Edo period, had furniture imported from the Netherlands upstairs and was called "the Dutch house"; it also had animals and plants from the country and was a famous tourist spot in Nagasaki.

The house of Kogu YOSHIO (Kozaemon), who was an interpreter in the mid Edo period, had furniture imported from the Netherlands upstairs and was called 'the Dutch house' where also had animals and plants from the country and was a famous tourist spot in Nagasaki.
sen.cmt: "the Dutch house"→原文は「」なので' 'に修正しました。; it→whereに変更しました。
sen.e: The house of Kogu YOSHIO (Kozaemon), who was an interpreter in the mid Edo period, had furniture imported from the Netherlands upstairs and was called 'the Dutch house' where also had animals and plants from the country and was a famous tourist spot in Nagasaki.

sen.j: 通詞以外の全国の蘭学者も多く師事した耕牛の家では、やはり太陽暦の元日に合わせ、オランダ正月が催されていた。
sen.e: Kogu had many pupils not only interpreters but also scholars all over the country, so he had Oranda Shogatsu party on the first day of the new Solar year.
Kogu had many pupils not only interpreters but also scholars all over the country, therefore he had an Oranda Shogatsu party on the first day of the new Solar year.
sen.cmt: Orandaの前にanを追加しました。so→口語なのでthereforeに変更しました。
sen.e: Kogu had many pupils not only interpreters but also scholars all over the country, therefore he had an Oranda Shogatsu party on the first day of the new Solar year.

sen.j: 江戸の蘭学者で指導的な地位にあった大槻玄沢も、この吉雄家洋間のオランダ正月に参加して感銘を受けた。
sen.e: Gentaku OTSUKI, a Rangaku scholar in Edo and who was in a leading position in the area participated in the Oranda Shogatsu party in the western room of the Yoshio family and was very impressed.
Gentaku OTSUKI who was a Rangaku scholar in Edo and was in a leading position in the area participated in the Oranda Shogatsu party in the western room of the Yoshio family and was very impressed.
sen.cmt: Gentaku OTSUKIの修飾語句が長いのでwhoに変更しました。
sen.e: Gentaku OTSUKI who was a Rangaku scholar in Edo and was in a leading position in the area participated in the Oranda Shogatsu party in the western room of the Yoshio family and was very impressed.

sen.j: 歴代のカピタン（カピタン）は定期的に江戸へ参府することが義務づけられていたが、大槻玄沢は寛政6年（1794年）のヘイスベルト・ヘンミー（Gijsbert Hemmij）の江戸出府でオランダ人と初めて対談した。
sen.e: All the Kapitans (curators of Dutch trading house) had an obligation to visit Edo regularly and when Gisbert HEMMIJ visited there, Gentaku OTSUKI, who met a Dutch for the first time, had a Shingenkai (New Year's party) on New Year's day of 1795 in the Solar calendar at Shiran-do school which was in his house in Mizutani-cho, Kyobashi with many Rangaku scholars and people who liked Dutch things.
All the Kapitans (curators of Dutch trading house) had an obligation to visit Edo regularly and Gentaku OTSUKI met a Dutch for the first time when Gisbert HEMMIJ visited there.
sen.cmt: 人まとまりにするには文章が長いので二つに分けました。一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: All the Kapitans (curators of Dutch trading house) had an obligation to visit Edo regularly and Gentaku OTSUKI met a Dutch for the first time when Gisbert HEMMIJ visited there.

sen.j: 玄沢は、これを機にこの年の閏11月11日が西暦で1795年1月2日に当たることから、京橋水谷町にあった自宅の塾芝蘭堂に、多くの蘭学者やオランダ風物の愛好家を招き、新元会（元日の祝宴）を催した。
sen.e: Gentaku took this opportunity to have a Shingenkai (New Year's party) at Shiran-do school which was in his house in Mizutani-cho, Kyobashi with many Rangaku scholars and people who liked Dutch things because on leap November 11 in that year fell on January 2, 1795.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処「これを機に」の部分が訳出されていないので、追加しました。「この年の閏11月11日が西暦で1795年1月2日に当たることから」の箇所訳漏れです。→ because以降で追加しています。
sen.e: Gentaku took this opportunity to have a Shingenkai (New Year's party) at Shiran-do school which was in his house in Mizutani-cho, Kyobashi with many Rangaku scholars and people who liked Dutch things because leap November 11 in that year fell on January 2, 1795.
sen.cmt: because on leap November 11→because leap month November 11

sen.j: ロシア帝国へ漂流した大黒屋光太夫なども招待されていた。
sen.e: Kodayu DAIKOKUYA, who was a castaway in the Russian Empire, was also invited.
sen.cmt: なぜ漂流した彼が招待されたことが重要なのか、その前の文章との関連から突然過ぎるような気もします。
sen.e: Kodayu DAIKOKUYA, who was a castaway in the Russian Empire, was also invited.
Kodayu DAIKOKUYA, who was a castaway in the Russian Empire, was also invited.

sen.j: これが江戸におけるオランダ正月の嚆矢となる。
sen.e: This was the start of Oranda Shogatsu in Edo.
This was the start of Oranda Shogatsu in Edo.
This was the start of Oranda Shogatsu in Edo.

sen.j: 記念すべき第1回の江戸オランダ正月は津藩の市川岳山が描く『芝蘭堂新元会図』で知られ、出席者による寄せ書きがされており、当日の楽しげな様子が十分伺える。
sen.e: The first Oranda Shogatsu in Edo was known from the painting of Kozan ICHIKAWA of Tsu Domain "Shiran-do Shingenkai zu" (Shiran-do New Year Party); with messages and signatures of the participants, it shows their enjoyment on the day.

The first Oranda Shogatsu in Edo was known from the painting of Kozan ICHIKAWA of Tsu Domain "Shiran-do Shingenkai zu" (Shiran-do New Year Party) with messages and signatures of the participants and it showed their enjoyment on the day.
sen.cmt: ;→削除しました。コンマをitに変更しました。shows→showedに変更しました。
sen.e: The first Oranda Shogatsu in Edo was known from the painting of Kozan ICHIKAWA of Tsu Domain "Shiran-do Shingenkai zu" (Shiran-do New Year Party) with messages and signatures of the participants and it showed their enjoyment on the day.

sen.j: 大きな机にはワイングラス、フォーク、ナイフなどが置かれ、部屋には洋式絵画が飾られている。
sen.e: On a large desk, there were wine glasses, knives & forks and some western style paintings on the wall.
On a large desk, there were wine glasses, knives and forks and some western style paintings were decorated on the wall.
sen.cmt: &にする意味合いが分かりません。削除しました。were decoratedを追加しました。
sen.e: On a large desk, there were wine glasses, knives and forks and some western style paintings were decorated on the wall.

sen.j: 出席者は他に玄沢の師でありすでに『解体新書』の翻訳で名を上げていた杉田玄白や、宇田川玄随などがいた。
sen.e: Among the participants, were Genpaku SUGITA who was already famous for his translation of "Kaitai Shinsho" (the historic Japanese translation of a Dutch anatomical text) and Geuzui UDAGAWA.

Other participants were Genpaku SUGITA and Genzui UDAGAWA who were Gentaku's teachers and already famous for the translation of "Kaitai Shinsho" (the historic Japanese translation of a Dutch anatomical text).
sen.cmt: 主語がありません。Among the participants, were→Other participants wereに変更しました。「玄沢の師であり」の箇所が訳出してありません。 Geuzui UDAGAWA→スペルミスです。
sen.e: Other participants were Genpaku SUGITA and Genzui UDAGAWA who were Gentaku's teachers and already famous for the translation of "Kaitai Shinsho" (the historic Japanese translation of a Dutch anatomical text).

sen.j: オランダ正月の背景には、8代征夷大将軍徳川吉宗による洋書輸入の一部解禁以降、蘭学研究が次第に盛んとなり、この頃には蘭癖と称されたオランダ文化の愛好家が増加していたことがある。
sen.e: As a background to Oranda Shogatsu, the eighth Seii Taishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) Yoshimune TOKUGAWA part-opened western book imports, which triggered a gradual boom of Dutch studies and the number of Dutch devotee, called Ranpeki who adored Dutch culture, was increased.

As a background to Oranda Shogatsu, Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, the eighth Seii Taishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) lifted the ban partially on the import of the western books, which triggered the increasing of Dutch studies and Dutch devotees, called Ranpeki who adored Dutch cultures.
sen.cmt: the eighth Seii Taishogun Yoshimune TOKUGAWA→Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, the eighth Seii Taishogunに変更しました。part-opened western book imports→lifted the ban partially on the import of the western booksに変更しました。
sen.e: As a background to Oranda Shogatsu, Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, the eighth Seii Taishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) lifted the ban partially on the import of the western books, which triggered the increasing of Dutch studies and Dutch devotees, called Ranpeki who adored Dutch cultures.

sen.j: 蘭癖らの舶来趣味に加え、新しい学問である蘭学が一定の市民権を得ていたことを受け、日本の伝統的正月行事に把われることなく、蘭学者たちが親睦を深め、自らの学問の隆盛を願い、最新情報の交換を行う集まりとして、以後も毎年行われるようになっていった。
sen.e: On top of those Ranpeki's favoring foreign goods and the fact that the new academic subject of Rangaku was receiving relative popularity, this sort of party was held annually following this, not being tied to traditional Japanese New Year events, but as the place for the scholars to get together and exchange the latest information to increase their knowledge.

In addition to those Ranpeki's pursuit of foreign goods, and the fact that the new academic subject of Rangaku became widely accepted, the party was held from those time, not being tied to traditional Japanese New Year events, but as the place for the scholars to get together and exchange the latest information to increase their knowledge.
sen.cmt: 単語の羅列が多いので適切な語句を挿入し、全文見直しました。
sen.e: In addition to those Ranpeki's pursuit of foreign goods, and the fact that the new academic subject of Rangaku became widely accepted, the party was held from those time, not being tied to traditional Japanese New Year events, but as the place for the scholars to get together and exchange the latest information to increase their knowledge.

sen.j: ただし、当時使用されていた寛政暦などの太陰太陽暦と西洋のグレゴリオ暦とのずれは毎年異なっていたため、便宜上、翌年以降は冬至（太陽暦でも太陰太陽暦でも同じ日である）から数えて第11日目にオランダ正月の賀宴を開催するのが恒例となった。
sen.e: However, because of the difference in dates between the lunar-solar calendar such as the Kansei calendar which was in use at that time in Japan and the western Gregorian calendar, for their convenience, they made it an established practice to have it on the 11th day after the winter solstice (which fell on the same day on both calendars) after that.

However, because the gap in dates between the lunar-solar calendar such as the Kansei calendar which was in use at those time in Japan and the Western Gregorian calendar differed every year, for convenience sake, it became an annual event to have a party for Oranda Shogatsu on the 11th day after the winter solstice (which fell on the same day on both calendars) since the following year.
sen.cmt: the difference→gapの方が適切な用語だと思います。後半theyやtheirなどの代名詞が増えているため、どのことを指しているのかわかりづらく、後半部分見直しました。
sen.e: However, because the gap in dates between the lunar-solar calendar such as the Kansei calendar which was in use at those time in Japan and the Western Gregorian calendar differed every year, for convenience sake, it became an annual event to have a party for Oranda Shogatsu on the 11th day after the winter solstice (which fell on the same day on both calendars) since the following year.

sen.j: 玄沢の子・大槻磐里が没する天保8年（1837年）まで計44回開かれたという。
sen.e: It is said that there were 44 Oranda Shogatsu celebrations until the death of Gentaku's son Banri OTSUKI in 1837.
It is said that there were 44 celebrations for Oranda Shogatsu until the death of Banri OTSUKI, the son of Gentaku, in 1837.
sen.cmt: Oranda Shogatsu celebrations→celebrations for Oranda ShogatsuGentaku's son Banri OTSUKI→Banri OTSUKI, the son of Gentakuに変更しました。自然な英語の流れを重視しました。
sen.e: It is said that there were 44 celebrations for Oranda Shogatsu until the death of Banri OTSUKI, the son of Gentaku, in 1837.
